qas.question: Where can oxonium ions be found?

answers.text: in acidic solution with other solvents

qas.question: What other term is a solvated protons referred as?

context:
To avoid the implication of the naked "solvated proton" in solution, acidic aqueous solutions are sometimes considered to contain a less unlikely fictitious species, termed the "<a1_0>hydronium ion<a1_0/>" (H
3O+). However, even in this case, such solvated hydrogen cations are more realistically conceived as being organized into clusters that form species closer to H
9O+
4. Other oxonium ions are found when water is <a0_0>in acidic solution with other solvents<a0_0/>.
